Award.AwardTitle: Geometry of groups and group actions
Award.AbstractNarration:
The long-term objective of the PI is to understand groups considered as geometric objects, the geometry and topology of spaces modeling these groups, and topological aspects of the group actions on such spaces. Specific objectives include the analysis and determination of higher dimensional filling invariants of groups, the establishment of foundational results for these invariants, and development of an approach to the relation gap problem via combinatorial Morse theory. The PI also proposes to study promotion maps and their properties, as well as applications to open problems.

Group theory is the theory of symmetry, which plays a fundamental role in mathematics. Patterns of symmetries (or "groups") arise very naturally in geometry, but also in other, more abstract, fields of mathematics. In geometric group theory one studies abstract groups by constructing geometric spaces, tailor-made for the groups at hand, in order to "see" the symmetry and better understand it. This project involves the detailed study of the geometric spaces thus constructed. In particular, it concerns the determination of shape and related properties of geometric spaces based on the nature of the symmetries they possess.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported basic research in the field of geometric group theory. This field broadly concerns the study of the geometry and topology of spaces admitting groups of symmetries; such study is a fruitful way of gaining understanding of the symmetry groups themselves.

 

The results of this project mostly touched on two areas in geometric group theory. The first area concerns isoperimetric problems and the computation of Dehn functions, and the development of new methods of computing such functions. We discovered new behavior within the realm of CAT(0) geometry, finding subgroups of CAT(0) groups possessing a wide range of possible Dehn functions. The spectrum of isoperimetric exponents of subgroups of CAT(0) groups was found to be dense in the interval from 2 to infinity, just as is the case with Dehn functions of groups generally. We also proved a conjecture of Bridson, on the isoperimetric behavior of the Stallings-Bieri groups, thus resolving a line of inquiry started by Gersten in the early 1990s.

 

The second area concerns stable commutator length in groups and their dual counterpart, the study of quasimorphisms and bounded coholomogy. We obtained general universal lower bounds in several situations. We found that in many groups, there is a gap in the spectrum of values of stable commutator length, above zero. This behavior was found in Baumslag-Solitar groups, in groups that admit actions on trees (for "well-aligned" elements), and in right-angled Artin groups. We also developed some new tools for the study of group actions on CAT(0) cube complexes more generally. These tools should have further applications.
